Instrument_PDS3.instrument_desc:
Instrument Overview =================== In the Boller & Chivens (B & C) spectrograph, the converging light beam from the telescope passes through the spectrograph entrance slit in the telescope focal plane to the collimator, an off-axis parabolic mirror. The reflected parallel beam then falls on the grating surface. The diffracted light passes through a Schmidt camera which images the spectrum on the CCD detector. The instrument and thus the slit orientation can be rotated fully within a 180 degree range and a readout accuracy of 0.1 degree. The slit width is set by a motor to a specified value between 50 and 890 micrometers.
The front surface of the spectrograph slits are aluminised and tilted slightly with respect to the incoming beam to allow the use of an integrating TV acquisition and guiding system. Guiding must be done by hand. Tracking rates for planetary motion can set.
In each exposure, spectra of 2048 pixel length are recorded for 100 or more spatial resolution points along the slit at 0.81 arcsec/pixel. The spectral scale can be changed by exchanging gratings. Although each spectrum is 2048 pixels long, the usable length is at least 10 % less since both ends of each spectrum are of degraded quality due to vignetting.
Scientific Objectives ===================== The objective was to determine the absolute albedo of the jovian planets and Titan at 1 nm or better spectral resolution throughout the spectral range accessible by CCDs. For small objects, Uranus, Neptune, Titan, and calibration stars, the total light at each wavelength was the only requested datum. For Jupiter and Saturn, the spatial distribution of light at each wavelength was of interest.
Calibration =========== Wavelength calibration is performed by an He-Ar lamp.
Flat-fields are taken at the dome illuminated by floodlights.
Operational Considerations ========================== At the beginning of each night, the grating is installed and tilted to achieve the desired spectral range, and the spectrograph is focused by staff members.
Detectors ========= The detector is a CCD: Ford Aerospace FA 2048 L, front illuminated, UV coated by EEV. It has 2048x2048 pixels of 15x15 micrometer size. The gain is 2.9 electrons/ADU. The noise level is 8 electrons RMS. Linearity is better than 0.2 % up to 85,000 electrons/pixel. The mean dark current is 2 electrons/pixel/hour. About 1.3 cosmic ray events occur per minute on the whole chip.
Filters ======= Order separating filters:
WG345: cuts off light below 345 nm GG475: cuts off light below 475 nm OG530: cuts off light below 530 nm OG550: cuts off light below 550 nm OG570: cuts off light below 570 nm
Other filter:
BG24: lowers light in the 500-650 nm region where the CCD is much more sensitive than in the blue.
Optics ====== Collimator: off-axis paraboloid of 750 mm focal length.
Schmidt Camera: focal length 143.5 mm.
Gratings:
Name grooves blaze blaze dispersion /mm angle wavelength ------------------------------------------------ # 5: 900 21o 10' 724 nm 0.13 nm/pixel #17: 400 9 44 770 0.28 #19: 600 17 27 910 0.19 #23: 600 8 38 455 0.19 #29: 600 5 10 300 0.19
Location ======== Latitude: 29 degrees, 15 minutes S Longitude: 70 degrees, 44 minutes W Altitude: 2400 meters
Measured Parameters =================== The instrument measures the brightness of the area of the sky the telescope is pointed to for a wide range of wavelengths. The spectra are generated by directing the light from the target onto a grating which differentiates the incoming light into its components.
